results.title: This is Victoria: Australia
results.brief_description: Silent footage of parts of Victoria and its people from the 1950s produced to promote Victoria. “The Rip” is the first sequence lasting approximately three minutes, where a family park the car to take in the view. They watch large cargo ships traverse the narrow entrance to Port Phillip Bay known as The Rip. Point Lonsdale is shown - the main street (full of fabulous cars from the era) and the lighthouse. Family beach fun is shown as children play in the shallows, people sunbake or rest in the shade of an umbrella, knit, go camping, wash baby in a big plastic tub, walk over the dunes, go surfing or play ballgames. “The Rose Chapel of St Helena” is a sequence approximately two minutes long about a small church in the Eltham/Greensborough area but before getting to that area there are a couple of shots of the City of Melbourne. The Chapel is shown, as are the gravestones from the 1850s that surround the chapel of this small Church of England. Some patrons and a clergyman are also in attendance. “Yarra Bridges” is the final sequence lasting about three minutes and it has some wonderful views of Melbourne and the Bridges that cross the Yarra River. St Pauls Cathedral over Princes Bridge, a view of the Governor’s Residence, cars, trains and assorted automobiles, a white helmeted policeman directing traffic, construction of pillars for a new bridge, the swing bridge at Yarra Bend and a Yarra River Boat Cruise are all shown.

results.title: Panorama: the state wide screen [excerpts No. 1]
results.brief_description: Excerpts from the Panorama documentary on the State Film Centre of Victoria. Candid footage of the goings on at the S.F.C.V. in Carlton in the early sixties. Customer service, despatch operations, film retrieving, checking and cleaning, and free film screenings in urban and rural areas.

results.title: Tullamarine project [original cut]
results.brief_description: A crowd waves goodbye to a T.A.A. flight at Essendon Airport, aerial shots of the City of Melbourne and Yarra River. late developmental stages of construction on the Tullamarine Airport and Freeway. Shot in October 1968.

results.title: [St Kilda Junction Overpass]
results.brief_description: Construction first began in 1970. This film explores not just the site construction but ambient shots of the surrounding traffic, footage of the W-class trams that graced the area and marvellous aerial shots of St Kilda, Albert Park and the newly constructed Dandenong Highway. (NOTE: Worksheet in HOLD file)

results.title: Skippy the Bush Kangaroo S01E20 "Double trouble" and S02E45 "Chicken"
results.creator_credit: Bob Austin, John McCallum, Lee Robinson, Max Varnel and Norfolk International Pictures
results.brief_description: Features two episodes of the television series. “Double trouble” looks at a rival who is trying to take control of the Waratah National Park; “Chicken” is about Skippy being poisoned by a local farmer who holds a grudge against the head ranger.

results.title: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @idkhowyoufoundme's TikTok stream
results.brief_description: Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, the man goes from confused to slightly defensive when he realises that he actually thinks about ancient Rome a lot. The viral meme seems to have revealed that men, collectively, think about aqueducts from antiquity regularly. It started as a text post on Instagram but has become a prank-style template, but it’s also sometimes considered alongside the red/beige flag relationship trend and the popularity of stoicism videos on the manosphere.
results.title_for_label: How often do you think about the Roman Empire?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, the man goes from confused to slightly defensive when he realises that he actually thinks about ancient Rome a lot. The viral meme seems to have revealed that men, collectively, think about aqueducts from antiquity regularly. It started as a question on Instagram but has become a prank-style template, but it’s also at times considered alongside the ‘red/beige’ flag relationship trend and the popularity of ancient Western civilisation on the misogynistic manosphere.

According to Know Your Meme:

Many are wondering if it’s a “red flag” if their male partner thinks about the Roman empire all the time. In some of the videos, the men sometimes answer “never,” and in the comment section, many women joke, “He’s a keeper.”

That intersection between the Roman Empire trend and the ‘red flag’ trend can be interpreted as identifying toxic masculinity. Online trolls and misogynists are at times inspired by examples of hyper-masculinity in antiquity as justification for a return to outdated gender norms. Ronald Levant, a professor emeritus of psychology at The University of Akron and author of The Tough Standard: The Hard Truths About Masculinity and Violence told USA Today that men may “gravitate to a society that glorified male strength” as they feel lost in the world.
description_for_label: Women asking men this question conquered the internet in September. What makes this example funny is the man’s surprise at such a specific question. Like most videos in the trend, he goes from confused to defensive when he realises he actually thinks about Rome a lot, like many other men according to the virality of the trend. Though a light-hearted prank-style meme, it can also be interpreted as demonstrating the link between idolising ancient Western history and toxic masculinity. To find out how, collect this display on your Lens and read more online.

details.label: Curatorial section

results.title: Xos: a cry for help
results.creator_credit: Alan Woodruff, Roberta Chuter and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Two transvestite brothers argue over the fate of their deceased grandmother: should she be buried in the family plot, or stuffed and placed beside her favourite dog?

results.title: Hey Marcel
results.brief_description: Images of figures descending staircases are orchestrated in four movements. Made with the assistance of the Creative Development Branch of the Australian Film Commission. Music by Bill McDonald; idea suggested by Chris Kennedy; lighting by Graeme Wood and David Lindsay. No spoken word.

results.title: My belle
results.brief_description: An impressionistic portrait of Michelle, a performer preparing for her act, caught between private and public worlds. Made with the assistance of the Creative Development Branch of the Australian Film Commission. Music by Bill Mcdonald and featuring Michelle Tozer. No spoken word.

results.title: Journey to the end of night
results.brief_description: Bill Neave, a World War II veteran, recounts his wartime experiences direct to the camera. The memories of these events are so vivid that he is still able to re-enact them and he does this on film, discussing such events with his long-dead friends. From an idea suggested and researched by Ruben Mow.
